Robert Langdon had become an expert on Freemasonry, Rosicrucianism and Martinism, but he was still having trouble tracing the illuminati, until one day Robert Langdon came across a very strange website claiming to be the official website of the illuminati order, which claimed that the illuminati possessed a religion that they had kept secret for centuries and of which only their followers had any knowledge. Celestia, who was the Grand Mistress of the Illuminati order, soon realized that Robert Langdon had connected to her site, which was extremely difficult to find, and could only be found by those whom the Illuminati deemed worthy of initiation into the order. Celestia therefore instructed his followers to initiate Robert Langdon, who was captured in his sleep and locked in a large room in which music clips were played with the indication that they came from famous media at the bottom of the image. Robert Langdon was very surprised to see that in his clips were all the Women he had been in love with in his life making declarations of love to him in clips broadcast on famous media. These clips rekindled the love that Robert Langdon had had for all these women in his youth, and he was literally struck with love by these clips sung by his childhood sweethearts. Robert Langdon had never had such a powerful experience in his life. After an hour, the room opened and Celestia, the Grand Mistress of the Illuminati, entered, saying to Robert Langdon: â€œYour initiation is complete, neophyte, all these clips were created by us and you have just been initiated into the power of the Love of the Supreme Goddess, who is the Goddess of the Secret Religion of the Illuminati Order.
Indiana Jones joined the Order of the Rosicrucians on March 29, 1945, and the first thing we learn from the first monograph on Rosicrucian teaching is that the Order of the Rosicrucians is divided into 4 study sections (1 postulant section, 2 neophyte section, 3 initiate section, 4 illuminati section). Indiana Jones only spent 1 year in the Order of the Rosicrucians, and only made it as far as Atrium 2 of the neophyte section, but the fact that the highest study section within the movement is called the illuminati section is enough to make conspiracy theorists all over the world wonder. The Order of the Rosicrucians revealed its existence to the public in 1614 with the publication of its first manifesto (Fama Fraternitatis), followed by Cofessio Fraternitatis in 1615 and Christian Rosencreutz's Noces Chymiques in 1616. The founding fathers of Freemasonry, one of the most influential organizations in the history of the world, were largely influenced by Rosicrucian ideas, which has led many esoteric historians to claim that Freemasonry is an offshoot of Rosicrucianism. It should also be noted that Freemasonry has a Knight Rosicrucian grade, which is the 18th degree in the Ancient and Accepted Scottish Rite and the 7th degree in the French Rite and its degrees or ranks are very high and prestigious in the hierarchy of Freemasonry. I loved this film. Seeing harrison don the costume again was alone pure bliss. 80 years old, running, jumping, swinging,  punching. The closure of Indy is closure for me. Raiders, Temple, Crusade, Crystal and Dial are the singularly most immaculate, passionate and joyful films ever created. Ill miss Indy, Salah, Shorty, Marion, Marcus, Mutt, Willy, Henry Senior and all the villians as well. 100% pure satisfaction  growing up, growing old with Indiana Jones. We, the kids from the 1980s, are the lucky ones. We got to see film in its purest, most creative state. I just watched Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny and I have to say it was a satisfying conclusion to the iconic franchise. Harrison Ford still has the charisma and the charm of the adventurous archaeologist, and his chemistry with Phoebe Waller-Bridge was delightful. The action scenes were thrilling and the plot was engaging, with some surprising twists and turns. The film also paid homage to the previous films, with references to the Ark of the Covenant, the Holy Grail, and the Crystal Skull. The dial of destiny was a fascinating artifact, with the power to alter history and reality. The villain, played by Mads Mikkelsen, was menacing and ruthless, and his plan was terrifying. The film also explored the themes of aging, legacy, and family, with Indy reconnecting with his old friends and his goddaughter. The film had some flaws, such as the excessive CGI and the lack of originality, but overall, it was a fun and nostalgic ride. I would recommend it to any fan of Indiana Jones or adventure movies in general. I give it 4 out of 5 stars.

Thursday_13_July_AD:2023_Post_Meridiem.  I viewed this movie today at EMPIRE CINEMA (SUTTON). Empire cinema is my choice of movie venue as this cinema is with luxury options. Today I booked a recliner armchair. My gratitude for Empire cinema's choice of chair cover, that is waterproof which helped my mental stability with hygiene as I sprayed and wet-wiped my seat.  I remembered the theme of Indiana Jones movies which I think is about an archaeologist professor/ teacher (Indiana Jones) with intellectual knowledge of archaeology with a mission to keep artefacts away from criminals and misuse so that items are documented and kept for reference as verification of historical occurrences in museums and libraries.  Though my focus was slightly distracted by stage whispering, This movie was enjoyable to watch. This movie has plenty of fight, chase action and interesting props. I found the first half of this movie thrilling and fast. It felt like the action slowed, however, I regained focus with fun scenes similar to earlier releases of Indiana Jones movies. The movie became equally entertaining towards the end.  I enjoyed the pace of the near pension aged actors (especially Harrison Ford) who sprinted and defended attacks upon him in several scenes. I enjoyed the original cast's appearance. I would have hoped for more footage of them.  On today's viewing, I felt as though the RGB screen settings were incorrect at Empire cinema (Sutton), as the picture seemed misty and blurry like an old film. The sound was okay, but seemed better quality in some scenes than others. I recall Empire cinema Leicester Square having better quality sound and lighting, as they used to have a jingle with thunder & lightning lights and sound effects. However I selected this screen having viewed options to have sound in the chair. I guess this would be equivalent to what I had at Empire cinema Leicester Square? I would hope for Empire cinemas to return the thunder, lightning display with sound effects, as it is effective which helped me choose the movie venue Empire cinemas (every time)  I hope that this is read by the technicians at EMPIRE CINEMAS.

Went to see this yesterday with family. We actually really enjoyed it, despite the tepid reviews everywhere. Harrison Ford puts in an incredible performance, and Mads Mikkelsen is just as dastardly an Indy villain as he was a Bond villain a few years ago :) My one quibble with the film - and yes, some of the reviews have picked up on the same thing - is that Phoebe Waller-Bridge in her performance was obviously going for "sassy and independent". Instead, her character just comes across as mean, selfish and unpleasant - to Indy especially - for most of the film, and it's only in the (no spoilers!) last 30 minutes or so that her character becomes vaguely likeable. Overall I'd rate this movie as better than "Crystal Skull" and probably on a par with The Last Crusade. Definitely a very fine coda to the Indiana Jones anthology!

Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny has some of the worst story-writing ever since the Indiana Jones trilogy. In order to prove this, I will jot down a much more convincing story-line from scratch. And to make it harder, I will even take the same starting point as the movie itself. The initial train-scene is generally considered the best part of the movie, so we keep that one. Skip to 1969. Embarrassing though this indubitably is, Indiana is an old wreck, a drunkard, who has lost all ambition in life. He and Marion are divorced, their son Mutt has died. Professor Basil Shaw is the specialist in the Antikythera mechanism. JÃ¼rgen Voller still wants to travel back in time to k**l Hitler in order to build an even greater Third Reich. So where do we go from there? Voller, after managing to climb up the ranks in the U.S. administration, finally is in a position to return to his initial quest. He needs the time machine, so he first turns to professor Shaw, but soon realizes that Shaw has only one piece of the mechanism and is otherwise useless to his plans. So he k**ls him, thus leaving Helena an orphan. With nowhere else to go, she turns to Indiana for help, but finds him in a desolate state and unwilling to help her. Meanwhile, Voller abducts Marion. He intends to force Indie into completing the mechanism for him. When he confronts Indie with this new circumstance, Indie and Helena agree to gather the scattered pieces of the mechanism in exchange for the life of Marion. They then head out, adventurously gather the parts, put them together and expect Voller to let them go after all. But this evil villain still needs them to operate the time-machine, so they have to accompany him on his trip back to his beloved Nazi time. With their help he actually manages to get there. He immediately hooks up with his younger self and they discuss the implications of changing the course of history. Both realize that k**ling Hitler will also eradicate Old-Voller. But Old-Voller is willing to sacrifice himself for the good cause, as Young-Voller will live to see the blossoming and blooming Reich to come. Indie, Helena and Marion manage to escape and disappear into the crowd. But when Indie tries to meet up with his own younger self, he is unfortunately caught by a search-party of Nazis who have order to arrest Young-Indie. Comparing Old-Indie with his mugshot, they make degrading remarks about how much he has aged in a few years. Marion and Helena witness his arrest and follow him to the building where he is held captive. Voller cannot be any happier, for Indie is now in that same building where he will place his bomb to execute Hitler. Of course, he cannot resist to brag in front of Indie about k**ling two birds, both his FÃ¼hrer and Indy, with one stone, because this makes him feel so overbearingly powerful. Indeed, Indie is unable to untie himself. Luckily, Marion and Helena can sneak in and help Indie out. Together they then discuss the implications of saving Hitlers life. After a heated debate Indie comes to the conclusion that World War II was indeed inevitable. As he has to accept the loss of his son in the Vietnam war, the world has to accept the losses that came with the World War. The future that Voller has in mind is by necessity far worse than anything that actually happened, terrible though it was. So they reluctantly set out to save Hitler's life. But when they find the bomb, just as they are hiding the bomb in the case they made for the time machine, the two Vollers step in, have them tied up again, grab the case with what they believe to be the time-machine and together they speed off in a victorious mood. The moment Young-Voller opens the case in order to take a look at the time-machine himself, he sees the bomb make its last few ticks before it explodes. Indie, Marion and Helena use the time-machine to get back to present day. Indie has gained a new taste in life and starts to appreciate his older age, because of the wisdom that comes with it. He and Marion reconnect, because of this shared adventure. And they adopt the orphaned Helena. Voila! The perfect Indiana V.

You know, Condorman might actually have a higher profit margin than this when adjusted for inflation  Number crunching time:  Condorman cost $14M to produce in 81, adjusted for inflation, that's $49M. Condorman lost Disney $6M in 81, $19M adjusted. Percentwise, thats about 40% lost for Condorman, Dial of Destiny as of this comment has lost either 45% or 50% (assuming the budget is $295M or $320M and box office of $160M). What does 50 cent and Indiana Jones have in common...they both got shot 9 times
Indiana Jones 5, "The Dial of Destiny", is the best of all five movies in the Indiana Jones franchise, in my humble opinion. The entire Indiana Jones film series seemed to be building to the message in this film. Indiana Jones, throughout his entire life, has been seeking treasure, and in this film, he finds his ultimate treasure: his family and loved ones. This is the entire point of Indiana Jones. It is the reason why he was content to walk down the stairs with Marion without the ark in "Raiders of the Lost Ark", the reason why he willingly returned the Sankara Stone to the village and left with Willie and Short Round in "Temple of Doom", the reason why he was able to let the Holy Grail fall into the chasm and leave with his Father and friends in "The Last Crusade" and the reason he married Marion at the "Kingdom of Crystal Skull." In the "Dial of Destiny", Indiana Jones not only regards his family and loved ones as his greatest treasure, but he inspires others, like his goddaughter Helena Shaw, to likewise treasure family and loved ones above any "fortune and glory" that may be out there. Dial of Destiny has an opening that immediately grips the viewer because it is so thrilling and Dial of Destiny has a heartwarming ending; one that leaves the viewer valuing the most important things in life. Indeed, Dial of Destiny showed that Indiana Jones' greatest treasure is family and loved ones.

I am not going to get political or get into race, sex, religion, etc. but objectively, this movie is trash. I walked out of a theater of 10 people feeling like my LIFE had been wasted. A movie so absolutely pointless and so horribly executed on every level that I was frustrated at myself for falling into the trap of seeing it in the first place. And just when the movie got to a point where I got close to feeling SOMETHING, it punched me right in the face. LITERALLY. Characters so stale and unlikable, you question whether this was written by a human or AI. I'm beginning to suspect the latter because I find it hard to believe that any creative in this industry, experienced or not, could allow such a POS to make it to final production. This movie is FAR WORSE than Kingdom of the Crystal Skull, and that's saying something.   You get the sense that there was so much executive intervention in creative control that James Mangold was left trying to paint the Sistine Chapel with his hands and feet tied. Dear Lucasfilm: STOP INTERFERING WITH THE ARTISTS' WORK. Leadership at Lucasfilm needs to be replaced. This is the last straw. People like me are just going to park our money elsewhere. go watch the trailer for the first film. Is it flashy and bombastic? No, it looks ripped from a VHS cassette and heavy on in-camera action rather than special effects However, it tells you that the Ark of the Covenant was lost, and has been searched for for thousands of years, that people aren't meant to have it, it's like a radio transmitter to God; it tells you that the power of the Ark can level mountains, that an army equipped with the Ark is "invincible" and that the Nazis are after it The film is set in 1936 before WW2, and it's only with the audience's hindsight that the Nazis were trying to conquer Europe that we understand it's a bad thing if they get it, so yes the trailer presumes the audience has this prior knowledge; however, crucially, the trailer sets up the stakes of "Indy must get the Ark before the Nazis do" and it even goes some way to explaining that the Ark possesses some divine power okay but what is this about? Indy wanted the thing, the bad guy's after the thing, the god-daughter is after the thing the Dial can "change the course of history" okay what are the stakes? what is the price of failure? the soundtrack and prior context puts this in the 1960s I don't doubt that the film will be competently put together from a technical standpoint, but I simply don't care, sorry

You stole it, then I stole it. It's called capitalism." This has to be the dumbest line in any of these movies. Even dumber than the, "What can I say, I'm a capitalist." line from Crystal Skull.  Theft and capitalism are fundamentally different. Theft involves unlawfully taking someone else's property, which is universally condemned. Capitalism, on the other hand, is an economic system that promotes voluntary exchange, private ownership, and fair competition. It's about creating wealth through innovation, investment, and hard work, rather than resorting to illegal means.

"Indiana Jones 5" is the upcoming fifth installment in the Indiana Jones film franchise. The movie is being directed by James Mangold and produced by Steven Spielberg, Kathleen Kennedy, Frank Marshall, and Simon Emanuel. Harrison Ford will be reprising his iconic role as the archaeologist and adventurer Indiana Jones.  The plot details for the movie have not been revealed yet, but it is known that the story will take place in the 1960s, which is a decade after the events of "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade." Some of the confirmed cast members include Phoebe Waller-Bridge, Mads Mikkelsen, Thomas Kretschmann, Boyd Holbrook, and Shaunette RenÃ©e Wilson.  The film is being directed by James Mangold, known for his work on movies like "Logan" and "Ford v Ferrari." Steven Spielberg, who directed the previous Indiana Jones films, is involved as a producer. The screenplay for "Indiana Jones 5" is written by Jonathan Kasdan, son of Lawrence Kasdan, who co-wrote "Raiders of the Lost Ark" and "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade."

Indiana Jones and the Scroll of Nirvana.  Indiana is gardening in retirement, but rumblings in India about the Scroll of Nirvana have been in Archaelogical News.  Archaeologists have been trying to find it for years, as it holds the rumoured encounter between Buddha and God on the Ultimate State of Nirvana, a state of perfect knowledge, peace, and amazing power.  If the scroll is found and uttered, the user could gain amazing powers, and Indiana, reluctant to leave the garden, is persuaded by old friends to join the search in the Himalayas of Nepal for the fabled scroll.  But so are Neo-Nazis, with the goal of resurrecting Hitler.

This trailer doesn't really do anything for me, in all honesty. It's not good, nor is it inherently bad.   It's just kinda average at this point for a lot of sequals to old franchises, with the constant tugging towards nostalgia, along with it it potentially being another nutzi, as if we don't already have two of those in this franchise.  Harrison is great and all, and kudos to him reprising his role, but honestly, with how things are on the story side of things, this series should've ended with either Crystal Skull, or better yet, with The Last Crusade, but nah.  I guess this is meant to be either one final hurrah for Indiana Jones as a whole, or more likely, just one final attempt to milk the brand for all its worth. Either way, I'm keeping my expectations very low for this one, especially with how sequals to beloved franchises have been for the last few years alone.

I love Indy movies and I love this trailer. I love the dialogue with Helena and Indy that calls back to the Grail and Indy -- growing older -- begins to shift into Henry -- HIS 'Grail" is this object. It's excellent, subtle movements and dialogue that illustrate this.   Other than the Cross of Coronado (which was only used as a side plot to illustrate how long Indy will play The Long Game"  The dial of Destiny AND the train were both very real.  While yes, there was a clockwork object located in an ancient shipwreck in 1901 -- the Antikythera Mechanism there is also the Rota Fortune, known as the Wheel of Fortune (buy a bunch of vowels)  The Rota was the "It" of the 13th century.  It became so well known it is part of The Carmina Burana, a Shakespeare play, the Canterbury Tales,MAY have a cameo in the Bible and continues to be one of the most powerful cards in the Major Arcana of the Tarot   It too was a weird mechanism that once the dial (inscribed with -- maybe -- Egyptian and Hebrew glyphs, are moved to align with four images on the face plate, you can hopefully Phone Home and alter the destiny of how Fate will reach its "Destiny"   Fate cannot be changed, nor can Fate which has already occurred be 'retconned''.  Per the Rota Fortuna, there are four paths of destiny that will determine the arrival and outcome of the specific Fate.  (it is like four creeks flowing into one larger river (which is Fate).  It is not a Time Machine, but CAN skip you THROUGH time to chose a different out come (Fate isn't as bad as conceived, Fate is worse, Fate takes a slight detour) And yep it existed -- and Fortune is Fickle -- you may 'dial your destiny" (which would be a great name for a Game Show, I am a research write for television)  It sort like, the proto Magic 8-Ball, a speak and spell and roulette wheel -- which is where Roulette cam from -- you can 'chose', hit HUGE or blow is all.  The Dial is in Charge.  and yeah the thing is still lurking around.    The train has a crate clearly marked ERR -- they were the division of the SS who drove around shopping for gold they could melt down into ingots, gemstones, famous masterpieces, and every other ar you can think of.  WW II buffs (me) all know about the 'famous' "Missing Nazi Gold Train" that apparently vanished into a tunnel or an abandoned coal mine.  It's said to be in Poland, BUT no one has ever found and spur tracks that lead off, or any indication that a loco and loot may still be hiding somewhere.  WW II buffs are pretty nuts on their field of combat, etc. they like to focus on, but you WILL eventually hear about this "missing" train.  I swear, if they decide "It's true ... all of it" and Indy dialed up "disappear" on the Rota, and becomes responsible for it actually disappearing.  I will stand up an cheer.   Voller (Mad Mikkleson) is a nastier version of Wernher von Braun, who yes, was a member of the SS (Mikkle is wearing Von Braun's precise uniform rank -- SS Major) Von Braun is in one photo wearing it, because Himmler dropped by that day to see what the 'Rocket Boys' were up to.  Von Braun and 500 other rocket scientist surrendered to the U.S. forces two days before Germany's official surrender -- and he STOLE A TRAIN to do it!  Yeah, Wenher was a Nazi, but Operation Paper (steal all the GREAT rocket scientists and ship them to the U.S. -- 1600 of them -- pretty much established NASA in the Space Race and you can thank a NAZI for landin 12 men on the Moon and bringing 36 safely back to Earth.    The Antikythera Mechanism has been partly restored and reads the courses of the stars and the planets, making in a super cool  version of an astrolabe, (it also was used for complex astronomy -- and no one knows what else the thing does-- it is often referred to as "the first or analogue computer". (this certanly explains the Hard hat dive sequence, I think they're after a missing part. it's been rumored that perhaps, it might have been able to mess with time as well, but they're stll scratching their heads over it and hopefully they can print up a 3D copy of it and figure it out -- and this is probably how we end up with Jurassic Park for real and don't take the I-10, because an apatosaurus is taking a nap on it and it's covering three state lines. Central characteristics of capitalism include capital accumulation, competitive markets, price system, private property, property rights recognition, voluntary exchange, and wage labor  No where does that say anything about theft. Playing around with theories as to how it ends:  1. Indy feels out of place in the modern era as an old man. Marion probably died and he misses her and regrets messing up their relationship. Indy goes into the past and changes his future to correct his mistakes. He watches his younger self avoid the mistakes he made, and then he dies there in the past. So it'd be a bittersweet ending as the Indy we know and love dies but a new Indy timeline is created (sort of like what Star Trek did with the Kelvin timeline).  2. Similar to the above except Indy realizes that if he changes his past then the Nazis win the war and/or his goddaughter will never be born, so he refuses the chance to change his past and returns to the present and dies as an old man having been at peace with his regrets.   3. Indy dies saving the day somehow in the past and ends up getting locked with the MacGuffin. Ending scene is in the near future in which his signature hat and whip are behind glass in a museum. Would be a tongue-in-cheek reference to when Belloq joked that maybe in a few years even he might be worth something.  4. Indy "dies" by being rewritten in the past and his goddaughter becomes the new "Indiana Jones". (Rumor that a friend of mine said was out there)

I remember when Temple of Doom came out as an 11 year old. I didn't actually  get to see Raiders on TV until 1984 (I'm origionally from the UK). I saw Temple of Doom in 1987 on TV but it wasn't until I saw Last Crusade in the theater in 1989, that I became a huge Indiana Jones fan that I am today. I don't hate Crystal Skull, but I feels that it pales in comparison to the original trilogy. From what I have seen so far, I feel that Dial of Destiny is going to redeem the last movie and I feel that James Mangold really understands the character of indiana Jones.

I think it would have been way cooler if the dial had turned out to be the compass from the pirates of the Caribbean movies. Firstly there would be the surprise of the reveal and fans pleasure of the franchise crossover. Second, an artifact that points you  the way to what you truly desire would actually be a very good McGuffin for an Indiana Jones film. Third you'd have that moment near the end of the film where the villain thinks they've, won, holds the compass, looks down at it but finds that the needle is just endlessly spinning. They would rage that after all this time searching for it, it doesn't work at which point Indie would then explain to them that the compass can't show them the way because there is nowhere for them to go. They've spent so long obsessing over and desiring the compass itself that they've forgotten what they ACTUALLY want out of life itself. This revelation would also allow Indie to accept and embrace retirement among whatever friends and family he may have now, instead of yet another quest to fill the void of loneliness.

I was born in 1980 and didn't really appreciate Indiana Jones until Crusades.   My pops and I went to the theatre for Kingdom of the Crystal Skull, and we're going to see this one.  For us, Kingdom represented Indiana Jones well, but ultimately failed to deliver the full Indy vibe because it deviated from the traditional Indiana Jones supernatural foundation.  Indy has always been rooted in religion.  The introduction of interdimensional beings clashed with the preconceptions of the issues that Indy and team would need to deal with, and challenged the audience with accepting theories often found on episodes of Ancient Aliens.    I for one hope this installment returns to the more mysterious, ancient aspect of the past and our interpretations therewith.

A native of Princeton, New Jersey, Indiana Jones was introduced as a tenured professor of archaeology in the 1981 film Raiders of the Lost Ark, set in 1936. The Joneses are a family of paternal Scottish descent. The character is an adventurer reminiscent of the 1930s film serial treasure hunters and pulp action heroes. He reacts emotionally and believably. Those are the two most important things in a franchise or even a stand-alone film, Plot and a believable, even likeable protagonist. The scenery and cinematography are outstanding, as well. I've watched the entire Indiana Jones Film Franchise from Raiders of the lost ark to Indiana Jones and The Kingdom of Crystal Skull. These films were simply breathtaking, brilliant, superb and spectacular. I'm looking forward to watch Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny when the film makes its way to the theatres on June 30. For me... I saw "Star Wars" (when I was 5 years old in 1980) before I saw "Raiders of the Lost Ark" (when I was 6 years old in 1981). However, Harrison Ford will always in my mind be 'Indiana Jones' first and 'Han Solo' second. I think because he was the actual main character in 'Raiders of the Lost Ark' versus being a co-character with so many others in 'Star Wars' ... it etched and solidified in my young brain that he is 'Indiana Jones'. Kind of like how Sylvester Stallone will always be 'Rocky' first and 'Rambo' second. I love them both, but my young brain etched him as 'Rocky' then 'Rambo'. Lastly, Eddie Murphy will always be 'Axel Foley'.

This cut makes it sound like a tribute and capping of Indiana Jones career, with Phoebe Waller-Bridge as a side kick. The initial cuts and industry leaks had it a Phoebe emasculates Indy and shows him how it's done before he dies/is erased from time, passing the torch to Phoebe who is supposed retrace his career replacing him to restore history. Fan outrage and disgust apparently prompted changes, but Indy is over budget and additional shooting was not authorized. Meaning they can only re-edit and use footage they already have. So as I see it, we will either get a mostly cringey girl power Mary Sue emasculate Indy movie and this trailer is hiding that. OR this trailer characterizes what they are actually trying to do now to salvage the movie. They will have to cut out and cut back Phoebe's emasculating as much as possibly while keeping the plot intact, probably resulting in a slightly disjointed mess that doesn't totally trash the hero but confuses/simplifies plot. In either case I would not bet on a good movie coming out if this. Hope I'm wrong, I love Indy and Harrison, and I'm still pissed about Han Solo! I don't want a repeat of Solo's pointless death.

Don't get your hopes up people. This movie is currently a hot mess.  The confirmed original ending of this movie had Indy use the Dial and cease to exist, allowing the girl to essentially take his place as the new "Indy" for future Disney+ projects.  Kathleen Kennedy is retiring as Lucasfilm's CEO. She doesn't really care how the film performs. She was going to get an Executive Producer credit in the next four Lucasfilm projects to the sum of $350 million... that was until Disney CEO Bob Iger gave his ultimatum.   With an average early screening score of 35%, Iger called Kennedy in and yelled at her saying "make it right, or you're losing your leaving bonus." Dial of Destiny needs to make at least $900 Million, or she leaves with nothing. Realizing Dial can't make that in its current state, she asked for a delay, Iger said no.   So, reshoots began. With reports of stunt actors in green screen suits who have no idea which characters they were portraying, desperate rewrites, and panicked CGI artists trying to cobble together a coherent story. This movie is shaping up to be a colossal failure.  *sources: Overlord DVD on YouTube

Can we cool it with the anti-capitalism remarks? Capitalism is not theft, it's individuals freely taking risks and making deals with each other to build things that people want to buy. It's people voluntarily working together to make cool stuff like this movie. The Indiana Jones films are themselves a product of capitalism, as is Lucasfilm and the Disney company, as are all of the actors and artists participating in this film. How many action/adventure films have you seen made in socialist or communist countries? Does the Canadian film board approve multimillion dollar flights of fancy like Indiana Jones 5? Do tax funded film programs give filmmakers enough resources to make this kind of film? Ironically, tax funded art is actually a kind of theft, while capitalist art is voluntarily funded by people who want to see it. Socialists don't get to choose what kind of films their taxes pay for, while people in capitalist countries like the US get to vote with their wallets for the films they want to see.

I saw Raiders of the Lost ark opening weekend back in 1981. Other than the Beatles, no creation of the arts ever influenced my own creative passions as much as that movie did. It made me feel like anything was possible. from writing to using a camera, acting or composing music. Something that started with seeing the film and creating new adventures with my Raiders kenner action figures, which has taken me to working in the entertainment business for over 30 years. while none of the sequels ever gave me the same joyous enthusiasm, I still go to see them. and I will be there in some imax theater routing for indy, and cheering him to beat the snot out of the nazis one more time.   While I am sure they will try to make Indy less flawed than he was originally so that no one is offended, I am able to look past that and have fun. But my hopes are, that they don't turn him into a bumbling old fool who is way too PC or as the nazis say "woke" for a man who was supposed to be born in the late 1890's... Indiana Jones was a rough, womanizing, cussing, intellectual who made many poor choices on impulse but recovered somehow by charm luck, good looks and brute force. Just like real people, he was Imperfect. please let's keep him that way and let's let him murder nazis with reckless abandon, just like many of our grandfathers did back when they helped liberate the world from nazi rule.   If this sequel sucks like part 4 did, I will not go on crusades blaming disney for ruining my childhood, cause my childhood was awesome and can never be ruined, but I will further be disheartened with the corporate take over of the cinematic experience. Raiders is not a marvel movie, and it should never be treated like one. it was the slower sequences in raiders that made the film FUN, relatable, and even believable. take for instance the entire sequences of Raiders from the Belloq and Indy bar room scene, to the part where Indy escapes the well of souls. it's these moments where you become involved with the story and Indy. It's where you learn the real beauty of the mystery of the film. the sequence in the map room particularly... films need space to breathe. especially in an action film. and that sequence IMO is what sells Indy. More so than any of the violence, explosions or stunts. I must confess I am worried that Steven Speilburg has stepped down from the directing roll of this installment. and something inside me feels saddened that this could possibly be a deeply disappointing window into the future of what is to become in cinema. I hope, I am wrong.

I was seven years old when I saw Kingdom of the Crystal Skull for the first time, which ignited my obsession with Indiana Jones. I'm 21 now, having waited 15 years for another installment, and it looks absolutely spectacular. A lot of trailers these days give away way too much of the movie, but this one shows you just enough to get you hooked. I have faith that Mangold will do justice to the franchise, but I'm not expecting perfection because nothing is perfect. And it's still Disney. But this trailer has boosted my confidence in it, and it looks like it'll be everything I could hope for from an Indy film. Humor, action, adventure, great characters, and good ol' Nazi punching. The de-aging looks magnificent, and I haven't seen any piece of media do it quite as well as this. I can't wait to see the flashback scenes with Indy in his prime. It'll be like watching the originals for the first time. Well, almost. Regardless, I know I'll be watching this at least 10 times in the theater. What a fantastic time to be alive!!!
